facts.text: High Court appeals arose from Judgment and Decree dated 23rd November 1936 of Subordinate Judge of Berhampore in Original Suit No. 11 of 1935.

anchor.surface_text: of 1939 arising out of the Judgment and Decree dated the 23rd November, 1936, of the Court of the Subordinate Judge of Berhampore in Original Suit No. 11 of 1935. V.

facts.text: Suit instituted by respondents to enforce mortgage deed Exhibit A dated 5th April 1923 executed by defendant in favour of Radha Prasad Bhagat.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AYYAR J.-These appeals arise out of a suit instituted by the respondents to enforce a mortgage deed, Exhibit A, dated 5th April,

facts.text: Mortgage for Rs. 1,25,000 on Bodogodo Zemindari in District of Ganjam, Province of Madras, comprised in State of Orissa, governed by Madras Impartible Estates Act II of 1904.

anchor.surface_text: 1923, executed by the defendant in favour of one Radha Prasad Bhagat. The subject-matter of the mortgage is an estate called the Bodogodo Zemin situated in what was the District of Ganjam in the Province of Madras and number companyprised in the State of Orissa, and governed by the provisions of the Madras Impartible Estates Act 11 of 1904.

facts.text: Mortgage deed recites Rs. 12,500 advanced on promissory note executed 30th March 1923, balance Rs. 1,12,500 paid in cash.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgage is for Rs. 1,25,000 and the deed recites that a sum of Rs. 12,500 was advanced to the mortgagor on a promissory numbere executed on 30th March, 1923, that the balance of Rs. 1,12,500 was paid to him in cash,

facts.text: Amount borrowed for expenses of marriage of defendant's second daughter with eldest son of Rajah of Talcher, marriage took place 27th April 1923.

anchor.surface_text: and that the entire amount was borrowed for meeting the expenses of the marriage of his second daughter with the eldest son of the Rajah of Talcher. The marriage, in fact, took place on 27th April, 1923.

facts.text: Plaintiffs' case: Rs. 1,12,500 paid on 14th April 1923 to defendant's manager Mr. Henry Tapp after mortgage registered on 10th April 1923.

anchor.surface_text: Though the deed recites that Rs. 1, 12,500 was paid in cash, the case of the plaintiffs is that it was, in fact, paid on 14th April, 1923, on the authority of the defendant to his manager, one Mr. Henry Tapp, after the mortgage bond was registered, which was on 10th April, 1923.

facts.text: Defendant made payments towards mortgage in 1926 and 1927 aggregating Rs. 42,000.

anchor.surface_text: In 1926 and 1927 the defendant made several payments towards the mortgage, in all aggregating to Rs. 42,000. The mortgagee died on 18th November, 1933,

facts.text: Mortgagee Radha Prasad Bhagat died on 18th November 1933, legal representatives filed suit for balance due by sale of property.

anchor.surface_text: and thereafter his legal representatives filed the suit, out of which these appeals arise, for recovery of the balance due under the mortgage by sale of the hypothecated property.

facts.text: Defendant pleaded mortgage supported by consideration only to extent of Rs. 25,000 and discharged by payments in 1926-1927.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant resisted the suit on several grounds. He pleaded that the mortgage was supported by companysideration only to the extent of Rs. 25,000, and that it had become discharged by the payments made in 1926 and 1927.

facts.text: Defendant contended mortgage bond not duly attested or validly registered, void and unenforceable.

anchor.surface_text: He also companytended that the mortgage bond was number duly attested or validly, registered, and that it was therefore void and unenforceable.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held no consideration for promissory note Exhibit J Rs. 12,500 dated 30th March 1923, it was salami, but balance Rs. 1,12,500 paid to Tapp under authority; bond duly attested and registered; passed decree.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge of Berhampur who heard the suit held that numberconsideration passed for the promissory numbere for Rs. 12,500 dated 30th March, 1923, Exhibit J, and that it was really a salami but that the balance of Rs. 1, 1 2,500 was paid to Mr. Tapp under the authority of the defendant. He also held that the mortgage bond was duly attested and validly registered, and a decree was passed in accordance with these findings

facts.text: Plaintiffs appealed in A.S. No. 10 of 1937 claiming consideration for Exhibit J; defendant in A.S. No. 11 of 1937 that payment to Tapp unauthorised, bond void not attested/registered.

anchor.surface_text: Both the parties took up the matter in appeal to the High Court of Patna. The plaintiffs filed A. S. No. 10 of 1937 claiming that Exhibit J was supported by companysideration, and the defendant filed A. S. No. 11 of 1937 pleading that the alleged payment of Rs. 1,12,500 to Mr. Tapp was unauthorised, and that the mortgage bond was void, as it was neither duly attested number properly registered.

facts.text: High Court concurred with Subordinate Judge that Rs. 1,12,500 paid to Tapp under authority, bond duly attested/registered; held Exhibit J supported by consideration.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court companycurred with the Subordinate Judge in finding that Rs. 1,12,500 was paid to Mr. Tapp under the authority of the defendant, and that the bond was duly attested and registered. But as regards the promissory numbere, Exhibit J, it held differing from the Subordinate Judge that it was also supported by companysideration.

facts.text: Defendant had been residing at Cuttack for a week prior to execution of power-of-attorney Exhibit B.

anchor.surface_text: With reference to the first companytention that the defendant was number residing at Cuttack at the date of Exhibit B, and companysequently the Registrar of that place had numberjurisdiction to register it under section 33  1   a , the finding of the companyrts below is that the defendant had been residing at Cuttack for a week prior to the date of Exhibit B,

facts.text: Power-of-attorney Exhibit B executed by defendant before Registrar at residence of Chief of Hindol at Cuttack, authenticated by him.

anchor.surface_text: In-the. present case, Exhibit A was presented for registration by Mr. Tapp as the agent of the defendant under a power-of-attorney executed by him, Exhibit B, and the question is whether that power satisfies the requirements of section 33. Exhibit B was executed by the defendant before the Registrar at the residence of the Chief of Hindol at Cuttack and was authenticated by him.

facts.text: Mortgage Exhibit A presented for registration by Mr. Tapp as agent under power-of-attorney Exhibit B.

anchor.surface_text: Where, therefore, a document is presented for registration by a person other than a party to it or his legal representative or assign or by a person who is number an agent authorized in the manner prescribed in section 33, such presentation is wholly inoperative, and the registration of such a document is void. facts.text: Defendant's son was studying at Cuttack at the time, residing in house of Chief of Hindol.

anchor.surface_text: It is also in evidence that the defendants son was studying at Cuttack at that time, and was residing in the house of the Chief of Hindol. Under the circumstances there were ample materials to support the finding of the companyrts below

facts.text: Defendant borrowed Rs. 12,500 under Exhibit J on 30th March 1923 while at Cuttack.

anchor.surface_text: He came there to companyplete the negotiations for raising a loan from Radha Prasad, and the execution of the power was only one and number a major incident in the business for which he came to Cuttack. As already mentioned, he also borrowed a sum of Rs. 12,500 under Exhibit J on 30th March, 1923, while at Cuttack.

facts.text: Supreme Court held mortgage bond supported by consideration and duly attested.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrt held on a companysideration Of the evidence that the mortgage bond was supported by companysideration and that it was duly attested.

facts.text: Supreme Court held power-of-attorney Exhibit B validly authenticated under section 33, even temporary residence at Cuttack sufficient.

anchor.surface_text: It must therefore be taken as settled that even temporary residence at a place is sufficient to clothe the Registrar of that place with jurisdiction under section 33  1   a .

facts.text: Defendant died while appeals pending, legal representatives prosecuting.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeals fail and are dismissed. As for companyts, it must be mentioned that the defendant died while the appeals were pending, and that it is his legal

facts.text: Property mortgaged governed by Madras Impartible Estates Act 11 of 1904; trial court found mortgage not binding on estate, High Court discharged finding leaving open.

anchor.surface_text: representatives who are prosecuting them. The property mortgaged is an estate governed by the Madras impartable Estates Act 11 of 1904. The plaintiffs alleged in their plaint that the mortgage was binding on the estate under section 4 of the Act. Issue 6 was framed with reference to this allegation, and the finding of the trial companyrt was that it was number binding on the estate. But on appeal, the High Court held that the question companyld number be gone into in a suit laid against the mortgagor. It accordingly discharged the finding, and left the question open to be determined in other and appropriate proceedings.

the provisions of the Madras Impartible Estates Act 11 of 1904. The mortgage is for Rs. 1,25,000 and the deed recites that a sum of Rs. 12,500 was advanced to the mortgagor on a promissory note executed on 30th March, 1923, that the balance of Rs. 1,12,500 was paid to him in cash, and that the entire amount was borrowed for meeting the expenses of the marriage of his second daughter with the eldest son of the Rajah of Talcher. The marriage, in fact, took place on 27th April, 1923.

The plaintiffs alleged in their plaint that the mortgage was binding on the estate under section 4 of the Act. Issue 6 was framed with reference to this allegation, and the finding of the trial court was that it was not binding on the estate.

anchor.surface_text: The last contention of the appellant was that the deed was not validly registered in accordance with the provisions of sections 32 and 33 of the Registration Act, and that it was therefore void. Section 32 enacts that, Except in the cases mentioned in sections 31, 88 and 89 every document to be registered under this Act shall be presented (a) by some person executing or claiming under the same, or (b) by the representative or assign of such person, or (c) by the agent of such person, representative or assign, duly authorised by power-of-attorney executed and authenticated in manner hereinafter mentioned.

concepts.interpretation: Imperative terms; presentation by unauthorised agent makes registration void and inoperative

anchor.surface_text: Section 33, so far as is material for the present purpose, runs as follows 33 (1) For the purposes of section 32, the following powers-of-attorney shall alone be recognized, namely - (a) if the principal at the time of executing the power-of- attorney resides in any part of the Provinces in which this Act is for the time being in force, a power-of-attorney executed before and authenticated by the Registrar or Sub-Registrar within whose district or sub- district the principal resides Provided that the following persons shall not be required to attend at any registration office or court for the purpose of executing any such power-of-attorney as is mentioned in clauses (a) and (b) of this section, namely - (i) persons who by reason of bodily infirmity are unable without risk or serious inconvenience so to attend...

concepts.interpretation: Temporary residence sufficient for jurisdiction; authentication at residence valid without personal attendance if bodily infirmity; presentation not required for mere authentication; registrar's satisfaction on infirmity is procedural, not jurisdictional

It also requires that they should be separately charged.

anchor.surface_text: In Ma Pwa May v. Chettiar Firm Lord Atkin observed In seeking to apply this section (section 87), it is important to distinguish between defects in the procedure of the Registrar and lack of jurisdiction. Where the Registrar has no jurisdiction to register, as where a person not entitled to do so presents for registration, or where there is lack of territorial jurisdiction, or where the presentation is out of time, the section is inoperative see Mujibunnissa v. Abdul Rahim. On the other hand, if the registrar having a jurisdiction has made a mistake in the exercise of it, the section (section 33) takes effect.

concepts.interpretation: Registrar's erroneous finding of bodily infirmity is procedural defect, not lack of jurisdiction; does not invalidate registration

issues.text: Whether the mortgage deed was validly registered in accordance with the provisions of sections 32 and 33 of the Registration Act?

anchor.surface_text: The last contention of the appellant was that the deed was not validly registered in accordance with the provisions of sections 32 and 33 of the Registration Act, and that it was therefore void. Section 32 enacts that, Except in the cases mentioned in sections 31, 88 and 89 every document to be registered under this Act shall be presented (a) by some person executing or claiming under the same, or (b) by the representative or assign of such person, or (c) by the agent of such person, representative or assign, duly authorised by power-of-attorney executed and authenticated in manner hereinafter mentioned.

issues.text: Whether the power-of-attorney executed by the defendant (Exhibit B) satisfies the requirements of section 33 of the Registration Act?

anchor.surface_text: In-the. present case, Exhibit A was presented for registration by Mr. Tapp as the agent of the defendant under a power-of-attorney executed by him, Exhibit B, and the question is whether that power satisfies the requirements of section 33. Exhibit B was executed by the defendant before the Registrar at the residence of the Chief of Hindol at Cuttack and was authenticated by him.

issues.text: Whether the defendant was residing at Cuttack at the time of execution of Exhibit B, giving the Registrar jurisdiction under section 33(1)(a)?

anchor.surface_text: It was argued for the appellant that the authentication was invalid on three grounds (1) that the defendant was not residing at Cuttack at the time of the execution of Exhibit B, and consequently the Registrar at Cuttack had no jurisdiction to authenticate the deed under section 33 (1) (a) (2) that Exhibit B was presented for registration by one Sundaram who described himself as the personal assistant of the defendant, but was, in fact, a person not authorised to present the document as required by section 32, and therefore the authentication of the power based on such presentation was void

issues.text: Whether the presentation of Exhibit B for registration by Sundaram was invalid under section 32, rendering the authentication void?

anchor.surface_text: that Exhibit B was presented for registration by one Sundaram who described himself as the personal assistant of the defendant, but was, in fact, a person not authorised to present the document as required by section 32, and therefore the authentication of the power based on such presentation was void and (3) that the authentication of the power under the proviso to section 33 (1) at the residence of the defendant was bad, as he was, in fact not suffering from any bodily infirmity at that time, and that consequently the registration of Exhibit A pursuant thereto was void.

issues.text: Whether the authentication of Exhibit B at the defendant's residence under the proviso to section 33(1) was invalid due to lack of bodily infirmity?

anchor.surface_text: Exhibit B was obviously produced before the Registrar along with the application for attendance at the residence for authentication and not for the purpose of registration. Rule 148 of the Bihar and Orissa Registration Manual provides both for registration and for authentication of a power-of-attorney, and prescribes separate endorsements for them. It also requires that they should be separately charged. Rule 157 provides that any person can present a document for authentication.

issues.text: Whether the mortgage was binding on the estate under section 4 of the Madras Impartible Estates Act?

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs alleged in their plaint that the mortgage was binding on the estate under section 4 of the Act. Issue 6 was framed with reference to this allegation, and the finding of the trial court was that it was not binding on the estate. But on appeal, the High Court held that the question could not be gone into in a suit laid against the mortgagor.

issues.text: Whether the mortgage bond was supported by consideration?

anchor.surface_text: The defendant resisted the suit on several grounds. He pleaded that the mortgage was supported by consideration only to the extent of Rs. 25,000, and that it had become discharged by the payments made in 1926 and 1927. He also contended that the mortgage bond was not duly attested or validly, registered, and that it was therefore void and unenforceable.

anchor.surface_text: Jambu Prasad v. Muhammad Aftar Ali Khan 1 , it was observed by the Judicial Committee approving of the decision in Ishri Prasad v. Baijnath 2  that, the terms of sections 32 and 33 of Act III of 1877 are imperative, and that a presentation of a document for registration by an agent who has number been duly authorized in accordance with those sections, does number give to the Registering Officer the indispensable foundation of his authority to register ,the document.

anchor.surface_text: In Sharat Chandra Basu v. Bijay Chand Mahtab 1  the Privy Council observed The expression resides, as used in section 33, is number defined in the statute but there is numberreason for assuming that it companytemplates only permanent residence and excludes temporary residence.

precedents.case_name: Sharat Chandra Basu v. Bijay Chand Mahtab
precedents.cited_proposition: expression 'resides' as used in section 33 includes temporary residence
precedents.cited_holding: The expression resides, as used in section 33, is number defined in the statute but there is numberreason for assuming that it companytemplates only permanent residence and excludes temporary residence.

precedents.citation: Sharat Chandra Basu v. Bijay Chand Mahtab 1

anchor.surface_text: In Sharat Chandra Basu v. Bijay Chand Mahtab 1  the endorsement on the power-of-attorney was as follows  1  64 I.A. 77 Executed in my presence at the Hazaribagh Registration Office on August 8, 1916, by Sharat Chandra Basu,

precedents.case_name: Sharat Chandra Basu v. Bijay Chand Mahtab
precedents.cited_proposition: endorsement on power-of-attorney as evidence of residence of principal
precedents.cited_holding: the endorsement of the SubRegistrar on the document expressly states that he was living, at that time, at Hazaribagh. The endorsement also shows that he was Personally known to the Sub-Registrar, and it is number likely that a mistake would be made about his place of residence.

precedents.citation: Bharat Indu v. Hamid Ali Khan 1

anchor.surface_text: In Bharat Indu v. Hamid Ali Khan 1 , apower-of-attorney executed by a mortgagor was presented for registration by his servant but actually the Registrar registered it at the residence of the principal under section 33.

precedents.case_name: Bharat Indu v. Hamid Ali Khan
precedents.cited_proposition: even if presentation of power-of-attorney for registration is bad, subsequent authentication/registration at residence under section 33 validates it
precedents.cited_holding: even though the presentation of the power for registration by the servant of the principal was bad, when it was subsequently registered at the residence of the executant in accordance with section 33 it should be deemed to have been presented by him to the Registrar, and that in that view the registration would be valid.

precedents.citation: Ma Pwa May v. Chettiar Firm 1

anchor.surface_text: In Ma Pwa May v. Chettiar Firm 1  Lord Atkin observed In seeking to apply this section  section 87 , it is important to distinguish between defects in the procedure of the Registrar and lack of jurisdiction.

precedents.case_name: Ma Pwa May v. Chettiar Firm
precedents.cited_proposition: distinguish between defects in procedure of Registrar and lack of jurisdiction; mistake in exercise of jurisdiction does not invalidate
precedents.cited_holding: In seeking to apply this section [section 87], it is important to distinguish between defects in the procedure of the Registrar and lack of jurisdiction. Where the Registrar has numberjurisdiction to register... the section is inoperative... On the other hand, if the registrar having a jurisdiction has made a mistake in the exercise of it, the section [section 33] takes effect.

anchor.surface_text: see Mujibunnissa v. Abdul Rahim 2 . On the other hand, if the registrar having a jurisdiction has made a mistake in the exercise of it, the section  section 33  takes effect.

precedents.cited_proposition: cases where Registrar has no jurisdiction, registration inoperative

anchor.surface_text: Exhibit B was obviously produced before the Registrar along with the application for attendance at the residence for authentication and not for the purpose of registration. Rule 148 of the Bihar and Orissa Registration Manual provides both for registration and for authentication of a power-of-attorney, and prescribes separate endorsements for them.
In the result, the appeals fail and are dismissed.
